title: glasgow-loyalist-band-refuses-withdraw-marches-council-regret-disruption
story: The Pride of Govan Flute Bands event, which is set to attract up to  marchers, will go ahead despite council officials asking organisers to call the parade off.The march is one of four loyalist parades taking place throughout the city on Saturday, which will go ahead after an announcement by the council that a public processions committee would not take place.Bosses at the council now say, in thecase ofthe Pride of Govan Flute Band, this is because police warned there could be serious disorderthe procession is prevented.:Four loyalist marches get Glasgow City Council go-ahead this weekendHowever, the force also said they would be able to police it either way.Last week, a decision was taken to prohibit all parades through the city over the weekend, with six loyalist and republicans events not held.However, loyalist and protestant groups gathered for a protest at George Square, claiming the move was illegal.A spokesman for Glasgow City Council has now said they were put in an impossible position.He added: "The council has been placed in an impossible position in relation to the parade in Govan.ldquoPoliceScotlandhas said that, should the procession not go ahead, many of the  people due to take part will react angrily - which could lead to violence and a signicant impact on the local community.ldquoWe deeply regret that the wider community in Govan will be subject to this disruption. However, police have made it absolutely clear that this could be made worsethese people are not allowed to march.ldquoThe council has asked the organisers to voluntarily withdraw this notication, which they have refused to do.":Glasgow MSP calls for reduction in lsquosectarianrsquo marchesEarlier today, it was confirmed the marches would be allowed to go ahead, despite police warning some form of protest and disorder was likelythe events were banned.Council officials in Glasgow have now appealed for those in charge to reconsider their decision and call off the march.A spokesman for the council added: "Today, we are directly appealing to them to reconsider that decision and think about the impact of their actions on the community in Govan and on tensions across the city.ldquoWe also call on other groups not to mount protests against the march.On Tuesday, the Pride of Govan Flute Band announced on Facebook that this weekends parade would go ahead.Band members have pleaded with those attending to remain dignied, claiming they will be under increased scrutiny after weeks of violence at parades and a protest last weekend, held by Scottish Protestants Against Discrimination .A spokesperson for the Pride of Govan Flute Band wrote: "The Pride of Govan Flute Band are pleased to confirm that our Annual Band Parade will take place on Saturday st September as planned."Due to circumstances outwith our control we will now be leaving from the Broomloan Road end of Ibrox Stadium at our original time of am, following a slightly dferent route to our traditional one, stopping at the Cenotaph to lay a wreath and hold a short service to pay homage to the men and women who made the ultimate sacrice to secure us the freedom we enjoy to this day."We invite the Protestant, unionist and loyalistcommunity to come along and enjoy the parade, we also ask that you respect our culture and conduct yourselves in a dignied manner."After the events of recent weeks, all eyes will be on us, all of us. Do not give our opponents or the authorities reason to question the PUL community."

title: John Humphrys calls it a day after 32 years on Today programme
story: Two past prime ministers, Dame Edna Everage, plus colleagues old and new from Jim Naughtie to Martha Kearney were in attendance ndash not a bad draw.The BBC Radio  show is not the big beast in the broadcast jungle it once was, having lost a few teeth and a million listeners in the past few years.But it is still a large enough feature in the media landscape to make the news as well as report it.For many, Humphrys is the Today programme, and his departure after  years and , shows is one for the diary.: Alison Rowat: Tories  And you thought the mafia had trouble resolving conflictTrue to form, the interviewer nicknamed the ldquorottweiler for his tenacious style, departed with a snarl and a few barks, before finally submitting to having his tummy tickled by admirers.The snarl was reserved for politicians who snub political interviews in favour of social media. In an interview with ex-prime minister Tony Blair, Humphrys said Boris Johnson had not been on the show since he entered Number  and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn had stayed away for nearly three years.ldquoIncreasingly, politicians are talking directly to the people via social media so they can choose the questions they answer without being challenged, Humphrys said.His encounter with David Cameron began with reminding the former PM of what he said the day before the  EU referendum: that whatever the outcome, he would accept the instructions of the people and get straight to work delivering them. ldquoThat was a  promise, wasnrsquot it  You misled the nation.Cameron thanked him for ldquo years of striking fear into politicians like me every morning and asking us questions that we donrsquot always want to answer.It was that kind of morning, when squishy compliments mingled with jagged political inquiry.It fell to Justin Webb to present a run through of the -year-oldrsquos career, stretching all the way from the Aberfan disaster to the Indo-Pakistan war of , Northern Ireland, Watergate and beyond.A move to presenting the news on television followed, but by  he was bored and an offer came to join Today. Clips of his former interviews were played, including the encounter which led to BBC director-general George Entwistle resigning.ldquoJohn is not a rottweiler, said Webb. ldquoThatrsquos the wrong dog.ldquoHersquos a terrier.Other colleagues piled in. This was not the occasion to recall past disagreements over pay or who landed the big interviews.ldquoThe annoying thing is he is often right, said Mishal Husain.: Andrew Marr Show, Sunday Politics Scotland, Ridge on Sunday reviewsldquoSo much time, passion, commitment, to whatever stories hellip Hersquos like one of those little bunnies with the long le batteries, he just keeps going on something, said Sarah Montague.Jim Naughtie said Humphrys had been ahead of his time on the environment, food, and waste: ldquoInside Seventies Man is a very twenty-first century man.And yes, after  years sitting alongside him in a studio, the Scotsman missed him.With the am pips looming, it was time for Humphrys to take his leave. There was an uncharacteristic faltering in the voice as he thanked listeners for their ldquoloyalty to the programme.ldquoI really do feel that I have got to know you over the decades and you are decent people, he said.ldquoIrsquom more proud than I can say that you have put up with me for so long. Thank you, all of you. I do hope you keep listening.ldquoToday matters for tomorrow andthatrsquos a rather corny way to end my years on the programme, so be it.Of listeners who had ldquowritten over the years, sometimes to give me a pat on the back, often to give me a kick up the backside for getting it wrong or for being out of touch, yoursquore always right, or nearly always.With that he signed off: ldquoThatrsquos it from me and from Today. Good morning.Later, the pro and anti-Humphrys camps had their say.Comedian Kathy Burke joked: ldquoIrsquove never been married but being furious with John Humphrys at least three out of five days every other week has felt like I was.ldquoThink Irsquom gonna miss the miserable old git. Good luck to him.Lord Adonis, former Labour Transport Secretary, tweeted his ldquodelight at Humphrys leaving, saying the programme needed big change.ldquoSo does BBC Question Time.

title: swinney-humiliated-another-flagship-plans-scrapped
story: Labour accused the Education Secretary of the ldquomother and father of humiliating U-turns after he said the  law behind the stateplan would be repealed without being used.However the Deputy First Minister refused to apologise to MSPs for the long and costly climbdown, saying the Governmentrsquos goal had been to improve the protection of vulnerable children.ldquoI will not apologise for trying to find the best way to try to do that, he said.It was the second high-profile retreat for Mr Swinney in just a few months.In June, he shelved an education bill which was initially touted as the centrepiece of the Governmentrsquos legislative programme after it too proved to be unworkable in practice.: MSPs pass move to stop Scottish Government spin on economyThe decision to ditch the named person plan was revealed by The Herald website yesterday morning, prompting Holyroodrsquos Presiding Officer to complain to the Government about a leak. Dubbed a ldquosnooperrsquos charter by critics, named persons was introduced to support the Scottish Governmentrsquos child protection policy Getting it right for every child .The scheme would have seen a named person ndash typically a teacher or health visitor ndash act as a clear point of contact for every child from birth until the age of .Ministers insisted it would formalise practices that were already in place in many parts of the country.However the plan faced a fierce backlash from parents and the professionals expected to put it into effect, and was the subject of a series of legal challenges, which cost taxpayers more than pound, to defend.In , the UK Supreme Court ruled that while the law establishing it, the Children and Young People Act of , was ldquounquestionably legitimate and benign in its aims, a central proposal to share information about children across ious agencies was unlawful.In particular, the court said it would breach rights to privacy and family le under the European Convention on Human Rights.In response, Mr Swinney set up an expert  to rewrite guidance to make the act compliant with the law and satisfy the courtrsquos concerns.But last month the  effectively gave up, reporting that redesigned information-sharing guidance was not the right thing to do and it was not possible to come up with workable rules that were easy for people to understand.Mr Swinney said parts four and five of the  act would be repealed and an information-sharing bill meant to fix the first problems would now be withdrawn.He told MSPs: ldquoWe will now not underpin in law the mandatory named person scheme for every child.ldquoInstead, existing voluntary schemes that provide a point of contact for support will continue, under current legal powers, when councils and health boards wish to provide them and parents wish to use them.ldquoIn that way, we will support our children and young people, so that they can thrive and rise to the challenges and opportunities that le brings.Simon Calvert, of the No to Named Persons campaign, which supported the Supreme Court challenge, said: ldquoJohn Swinney has finally done the right thing ndash but not before time. This is good news for families all across Scotland and itrsquos a great relief for a lot of people.ldquoI think he still owes an apology to families for insisting on still trying to get legislation through that breached their human rights, and he has a big job of work to do to unpick all of the legally inaccurate training that his Government has been giving to officials all across Scotland for years.Tory MSP Liz Smith said: ldquoThis is a complete humiliation for the SNP.ldquoJohn Swinney should apologise to all the professionals on the front line faced with endless bureaucracy around this policy and the anxiety of not knowing where their legal responsibilities lay. It is very welcome news that this policy will now be consigned to the dustbin.Labourrsquos Iain Gray said: ldquoThis whole process has been a shambles. The principle of the named person scheme was a good one but it has been destroyed by the incompetence of successive SNP ministers.: Sturgeon tells colleges not to punish student climate strikersldquoThey lost control of the policy, lost the confidence and support of practitioners, parents and the public, then lost the challenge in the supreme court.ldquoTo have to abandon one bill and repeal another in one day is an unprecedented humiliation for John Swinney.ldquoIt is not the first time either ndash he had to drop his flagship education bill.ldquoJohn Swinney was meant to be a lsquosafe pair of handsrsquo, but he has dropped the ball yet again.LibDem MSP Alex Cole-Hamilton added: ldquoThis is yet another humiliation for the Education Secretary and his Government.ldquoThe Scottish Government has wasted years of time and the goodwill of the people from the childrenrsquos sector involved in the policy. It lost the confidence of parents and frontline professionals. We all want to see mechanisms to help keep children safe but this SNP plan was impossible to implement.A Scottish Government spokesman said: ldquoWe are investigating how details of the statement were reported on before they were communicated to Parliament.

title: cake-store-owners-shaken-receiving-homophobic-letter-customer
story: A COUPLE have said they are horried after receiving a hateful, homophobic letter to their store demanding a refund due to their sexualityThe shop owners, husband and husband pair Michael Burns and Stephen Whyteside, receivedthe shocking piece of mail on Thursday morning.: years of Stonewall: The fight for LGBT rightsStaff at the store, who opened theenvelope directed to Special Days Cakes in Uddingston, were distraught and upset after reading the contents, which threatened that the company "should be shut down".Michael, left, and Stephen, rightAfter showroom workers calledMichael, , and Stephen, , the happy couple reported the hate crime to police, who are now said to be investigating the package sent to the store on Old Edinburgh Road.The shocking letter, which we have printed below, contains multiple anti-gay slurs and reports disgust at Michael and Stephens sexuality.In it, the writer tells thattheyhad known they were gay they would have "given the shop a wide berth".It goes on: "I will be ing to get my money back as I dont want any of your hands near any food."You should be shut down.": Peace TV censored by Ofcom for calling gay people worse than animalsJust  hours after getting the note, Michael and Stephensay they are still shaken up.Showroom manager Stephen told The Evening Times: "Staff opened the letter and were very upset, especially when they had to tell us what it contained. Having to read this and then call us, it is terrible.Special Days Cakes"I started laughing at first, I just thought it couldnt be real. You dont get letters like that."Im just so shocked that someone would take the time to do anything like this."This is not something that ever happens. Weve not had any disagreements with customers, theyre not the type to do that. The fact that were a couple isnt hidden, it is promoted."It seems someone has gone out of their way to target us with this hate crime."For the first time in forever we had a terrible nights sleep - we were both up checking cameras. We were worriedsomeone has gone to the effort to find out shop, why not our home "The couple, from Bothwell, have been together for  years and will celebrate their tenth wedding anniversary in December.Michael and Stephen on their wedding dayMichael, who started Special Days Cakes  years ago in his home town, welcomed Stephen onto the team nearly  years ago, and the pair say they have never hidden their relationship from customers.Police have now been made aware of the incident and will speak to the owners on Friday afternoon about the note.However, despite the hateful letter, which is printed below, the couple say they have been reassured by the kind messages of support they have had online, where Michaels photo of the letter has been shared almost , times.Stephen added:"Police have been really good and they are coming out this afternoon to take the letter for fingerprints and DNA testing."Were involved in community and charity work - people know we are a couple!"This is not something weve ever dealt with before or ever had to hide. I was brought up in Scotland where it was okay to be who you are. This is the first time I have felt otherwise."But we have had messages of support on social media - other cake shops in London have even written to us. Its great to be somewhere where people stand by you."Both of us are upbeat, but its still in the back of our mind. Why did they go to all of this effort "The letter received by Michael and StephenThe letter, which is addressed to the store and was stamped and posted, reads:Dear poofs,If I had known that you were fucking gay then I would have given your shop a wide berth.I will be ing to get my money back as I dont want any of your hands near any food.You should be shut down.Ya fucking queer poofy pricks.For any help or advice on issues touched upon in this article, visit the Equality Networks LGBT Helpline or emailhelpline@lgbthealth.org.uk. Alternatively, you can call   . ##

title: women-fore-new-rbs-boss-vows-shake-status-quo-good
story: Now Alison Rose is determined that many other young women will follow in her footsteps and reach the top of their profession.Ms Rose has previously said it is her mission to change the male-ominated banking profession that she joined  years ago as a graduate trainee.Ms Rose, who joined the bank  years ago as a graduate trainee, will replace the incumbent Ross McEwan in November.She will be paid more than her predecessor, with her annual salary set at pound.m compared with Mr McEwans poundm.When she attended her first meeting as a senior RBS executive, she was the only woman in the boardroom.Now, one-third of the top  posts are held by women, but Ms Rose wants to go further and hopes that she is the ideal role model for young females to look up to.She said: ldquoWe have made great strides but there is still a long way to go.ldquoI do see myself as a positive role model and I hope that young women will aspire to reach the top."Other lenders have been led by women. Ana Botin was formerly in charge of Santander UK, while Dame Jayne-Anne Gadhia was chief executive of Virgin Money before it was sold to CYBG last year.However, Ms Rose is the only woman so far to lead one of the UKs four biggest banks, which are RBS, Lloyds Banking Group, Barclays and HSBC.Ms Rose does acknowledge the seismic change that will be sent out after becoming the first female head of a major high street bank in the UK.For her, it sends out the best possible message to the , extra women she wants to help set up their own business by .Currently, just one in three entrepreneurs is female, while in some other European countries the rate is more than  per cent.It is a situation that she is desperate to change and hopes her report will lead to a dramatic increase in female businesswomen.She said: ldquoThe scale of the ambition is considerable and in my view we now have our North Star to aim for, a % increase in female entrepreneurs.ldquoThat will act as a guide to joined up action across public and private sector.Women make up more than half the population in Britain, but just one in five businesses is female-run, a figure recently described as ldquoshocking by Robert Jenrick, exchequer secretary to the Treasury.With Ms Rosersquos encouragement, RBS has created a network of  NatWest Entrepreneur Accelerator hubs around the country.These are where would-be entrepreneurs can get help with the nuts and bolts of finding start-up funds and writing business plans from a team of women advisers.She said: ldquoItrsquos a big responsibility but itrsquos something I feel passionately about ldquoThe most important thing to remember is that itrsquos never perfect.ldquoEven when yoursquove got support and yoursquore very organised, things always go wrong. It is a juggling, balancing and complicated act.She joined National Westminster Bank as a trainee in  after graduating from Durham University.By the time RBS took over NatWest in , Ms Rose was working her way through a series of jobs in the investment banking ision, which ultimately put her in charge of leveraged finance in the UK and Europe.She helped restructure the balance sheet in the aftermath of the financial implosion and in  took over commercial and private banking, which now accounts for nearly half of assets at the group.She refuses to be drawn on the bankrsquos major challenges in the coming months, particularly with Brexit.The bank has already relocated some jobs to Amsterdam in case of a no-deal exit.Ms Rose admits that while RBS has restored some of its badly tarnished reputation there is still some way to go.She said: ldquoItrsquos been a very dficult time but we are working hard to restore it by trying to improve things for customers. I believe we have made a lot of progress in improving things, but we are not complacent.And it seems she sees it as her responsibility to inspire others too.One major area that needs to be addressed, according to Ms Rose, is getting girls exposed to female entrepreneurs and get them interested in Stem subjects which offer the highest growth for businesses.Ms Rose said: ldquoThere are not enough women in high-growth fields and that is also holding many back.ldquoBy going into schools then we can provide young girls with a role model they need to aspire too. By the time they get to college it is normally too late.ldquoThere are real and practical steps that can and will be taken. Maintaining the status quo is not an option.

title: sturgeon-confirms-yes-vote-independence-reversed
story: The First Minister said she thought such an outcome was unlikely, but acknowledged democracy meant people would be entitled to cancel a Yes vote though another referendum.The previously unreported comments, made in Berlin on Wednesday, are likely to fuel calls for a confirmatory vote being made a precondition of holding Indyref.They also suggest the aftermath of any Yes vote could be as politically turbulent as the one following Brexit, as Unionists could try to have the result overturned.Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoAs soon as you say a referendum result is irreversible, by definition itrsquos not democratic."Becausepeople change their mind, orcircumstances change, thentheyrsquore not allowed to change the decision, then itrsquos not democratic.Asked directlya vote for independence could be reversed by a later vote for the Union, she accepted it was a possibility, adding: ldquoItrsquos up to people to decide the future they want.The Scottish LibDems and Tories said it was a recipe for endless ldquochaos.Ms Sturgeon has said she wants another vote on the constitution next year, but the UK Tory Government has so far refused to grant Holyrood the necessary powers to hold it.Labour has said it is open to a second referendum, provided Nationalist parties win a fresh and unambiguous mandate, with some Labour MPs also pushing for a confirmatory vote on the outcome of independence negotiations between Edinburgh and London.Ms Sturgeonrsquos remarks are fully consistent with her desire to revisit the No result of the  referendum and the Brexit result of the  referendum.However they will dismay parts of the Yes movement, including some SNP MPs, who warned her not to set a precedent by backing a second Brexit referendum in case it opened the door to Unionist challenges to independence.The SNP Governmentrsquos  White Paper on Independence was silent on the possibility of a further referendum, declaring that independence would follow  months of negotiations.Senior SNP politicians also try to avoid hypothetical questions about a Yes vote possibly being overturned.But Ms Sturgeon, in Germany to meet politicians and business leaders and receive a media prize for being a ldquovoice of reason on Brexit, was unable to escape her own logic on the issue.At a press conference at the German Council on Foreign Relations, she was asked by a Czech news agency reporterthere would be a third independence referendumshe lost Indyref.After saying she thought Scotland would back independence, she said: "No politician can decide that a country no longer has the ability to choose its own future. Somebody in the Brexit context in the UK last week or the week before made the point that referendums can either be irreversible or they can be democratic, they canrsquot be both.ldquoBecause as soon as you say a referendum result is irreversible, by definition itrsquos not democratic."Becausepeople change their mind, orcircumstances change, thentheyrsquore not allowed to change the decision, then itrsquos not democratic.ldquoSo at the end of the day, itrsquos up to people to decide the future of Scotland, as it is up to people to decide the future of any country.When askedthat logic applied to independence, she did not dispute it. She was asked: ldquoSo that would mean,the Scottish people decide for independence, there could also be a next referendum in a few years for the Scottish people to decide against independence again "That would be OK with you Ms Sturgeon replied: ldquoDemocracyrsquos not conditional. Itrsquos not for politicians to decide the limits that they place on democracy. Itrsquos up to people to decide the future they want.ldquoBut no country, to my knowledge, that has become independent from the UK... and I think since the end of the Second World War I think there have been several countries that have become independent from the UK, none of them have decided to change their minds and go back the way, and I donrsquot think that it is likely that Scotland would do that either.Scottish LibDem leader Willie Rennie said: ldquoSNP supporters will go bananas to hear the First Minister is lining up Indyref as well as Indyref. We want to make this chaos stop.Tory MSP Adam Tomkins said: ldquoIf people are sick of the prospect of Indyref, theyrsquoll be even more angry to hear the First Minister on Indyrefs and . Participating in and agitating for referendums is the only thing that keeps Nicola Sturgeon in business.ldquoSo itrsquos perhaps unsurprising that she never wants the cycle to end. There is one solution to this problem ndash take the threat of a referendum off the table altogether, then no-one need worry about the status of the outcome. People in Scotland are sick of referendums, and will be concerned to hear the First Ministerrsquos appetite for more.

title: kevin-mckenna-catholic-schools-don-39-t-cause-sectarianism-cure
story: The nation was now set fair on its voyage of devolved self-discovery fortied by perhaps the most beautul, secular testament to human dignity ever created. No matter what might befall Scotland and how it might be governed in future the basic human rights of its citizens, respecting their faith, sexual orientation, race and political beliefs were now deemed to be sacred. In future there might still be greed and corruption and malfeasance at the heart of public le and in the grand offices of state but the people had now been empowered by something greater than them all.The beauty of the ECHR lies not merely in the clarity and nobility of its language but in the way that no detail pertinent to the peace and happiness of the inidual is overlooked. Article  in the substantive protocols to the ECHR has this to say about education. ldquoNo person shall be denied the right to education. In the exercise of any s which it assumes in relation to education and to teaching, the State shall respect the right of parents to ensure such education and teaching is in conformity with their own religious and philosophical convictions.This protocol seemed to reinforce another great legislative testament to Scottish enlightened and progressive thinking, the  Education Act. This guaranteed the right of Scotlandrsquos Catholic population to have their children educated by the state according to the norms and mores of their faith. The Act wasnrsquot an endorsement of religious indoctrination it didnrsquot grant a licence for sectarianism. It was simply an acknowledgment of the important role that faith plays in the lives of many of its citizens. Following the harrowing experiences of the Great War it was also an acknowledgement by the state that Catholic children, ravaged by high levels of malnutrition and the effects of multi-deprivation, might be needed to fight any future existential threat to our freedoms and democracy.For more than a century now Scotlandrsquos Catholic schools have flourished and are regularly found to have excelled, under strict inspection, beyond the boundaries of their initial remit. Over several decades when the influx of Irish-Catholic refugees fleeing the Great Famine risked inflaming tensions with the indigenous Protestant working classes the existence of these schools has helped in the process of peaceful integration. They act as bridges where the old and cherished beliefs of a religious minority can meet and converse with the greater Scotland beyond. In disadvantaged neighbourhoods they continue to perform heroically and offer children in these places hope and a slender chance of a rewarding le. Scotland should be proud of them. And we Scots of Irish-Catholic stock should be proud too that we live in a country which cherishes dference and ersity and values our communityrsquos distinctive contribution to its public le.Nicola Sturgeon recognised this last year at a celebration to mark  years of Scotlandrsquos Catholic schools. She said: ldquo is the centenary of the legislation that brought Roman Catholic schools into Scotlandrsquos state education system. In that time, Catholic schools have made a tremendous contribution to Scottish education, and this is something we want to see continue. We value the contribution that Catholic schools make to modern Scotland. We want that contribution to continue in the years ahead.One year on from the First Ministerrsquos eloquent endorsement attacks on Catholic schools remain predictably depressing. The most recent follow skirmishes in Glasgow earlier this month when an Irish republican parade was confronted by protesters. Predictably, this was portrayed as another outbreak of religious sectarianism. Yet, it probably owed more to the current heightened tensions surrounding the prospect of a hard Brexit, the Irish border and inflamed British nationalism. In a remarkably ignorant and badly-written article a former deputy chief constable in Police Scotland used this isolated and rare occurrence to justy shutting Catholic schools. ldquoWe also need to look at the roots of the problem and question what ides us, he wrote. ldquoAndwe do that then we simply cannot escape questioning our system of religiously segregated education. His words were a sinister reminder of why large sections of the Irish-Catholic community traditionally beheld Scotlandrsquos police forces with deep mistrust.The independent Advisory Committee on Tackling Sectarianism set up by the Scottish Government has produced several wide-ranging and exhaustive reports. These specically and unequivocally stated that Catholic schools were not even remotely a cause of sectarianism in Scotland. It also pointed out that, in any case, sectarianism was largely in retreat in modern Scotland.So, in the absence of any evidence that Catholic schools contribute to sectarianism and in spite of counter-data that they actually foster multi-culturalism and tolerance what lies at the root of these attacks  Letrsquos speak frankly here. The people who are most vocerous in their hostility towards Catholic schools also purport to cherish ersity and equality. Yet they want these only within the bounds of a narrow and illiberal agenda. It is group-think that relies on old and discredited tropes that were once used to alienate and target minorities. These people simply donrsquot like the idea of Catholic schools but have nothing to justy their hostility. Each year they are reduced to scanning Scotlandrsquos cultural horizon looking for any little wrinkles that can be swollen into  outrage.Professor Sir Tom Devine, Scotlandrsquos foremost historian, said of this: ldquoIf there was one action certain to inflame sectarian tensions in Scotland it would be any suggestion from the Scottish lrmGovernment of an intention to abolish Catholic schools. That would rightly be regarded as an attack on the Catholic community itself.Laughably, the same people who attack Catholic schools are often to be found in the cultural vanguard that disdains Orange Parades. Of course, nice, well-dressed climate and political protests where we all stop for croissants and smoothies at some chi-chi deli are deemed acceptable. But Orange parades where the marchers, often poor, are hanging on to that pillar of their existence that lends meaning to their lives are considered beyond the pale. Not for the first time this Scot of Irish-Catholic heritage finds more common ground with the Orange Order than with the intolerant liberals who seek to ban their walks. It seems that we have a common and implacable enemy.

it was a recipe for endless ldquochaos.:Paul Hutcheon: In indyref, the stakes would be so much higher for UnionistsMs Sturgeon has said she wants another vote on the constitution next year, but the UK Tory Government has so far refused to grant Holyrood the necessary powers to hold it.Labour has said it is open to a second referendum, provided Nationalist parties win a fresh and unambiguous mandate, with some Labour MPs also pushing for a confirmatory vote on the outcome of independence negotiations between Edinburgh and London.Ms Sturgeonrsquos remarks are fully consistent with her desire to revisit the No result of the  referendum and the Brexit result of the  referendum.However they will dismay parts of the Yes movement, including some SNP MPs, who warned her not to set a precedent by backing a second Brexit referendum in case it opened the door to Unionist challenges to independence.The SNP Governmentrsquos  White Paper on Independence was silent on the possibility of Sturgeon, in Germany to meet politicians and business leaders and receive a media prize for being a ldquovoice of reason on Brexit, was unable to escape her own logic on the issue.:Jeremy Corbyn will Somebody in the Brexit context in the UK last week or the week before made the point that referendums can either be irreversible or they can be democratic, they canrsquot be both.ldquoBecause as soon as you say a referendum result is irreversible, by definition itrsquos not democratic.ldquoBecausepeople change their mind, orcircumstances change, thentheyrsquore not allowed to change the decision, then itrsquos not democratic.ldquoSo at the end of the day, itrsquos up to people to decide the future of Scotland, as it is up to people to decide the future of any country.When askedthat logic applied to independence, she did not dispute it. She was asked: ldquoSo that would mean,the Scottish people decide for independence, there could also be a next referendum in a few years for the Scottish people to decide against independence again ldquoThat would be OK with you Ms Sturgeon replied: ldquoDemocracyrsquos not conditional. Participating in and agitating for referendums is the only thing that keeps Nicola Sturgeon in business.ldquoSo itrsquos perhaps unsurprising that she never wants the cycle to end. There is one solution to this problem ndash take the threat of a referendum off the table altogether, then no-one need worry about the status of the outcome. People in Scotland are sick of referendums, and will be concerned to hear the First Ministerrsquos appetite for more.The SNP were asked for comment.

title: labour-conference-opens-corbyn-39-s-rating-39-historically-dire-39
story: As delegates gather in Brighton, large sections of the party and the shadow cabinet will try to make Labour an unambiguous party of Remain in the coming electoral fight.Mr Corbyn wants the party to offer voters a referendum on BrexitLabour wins the election, but he would then not take a side in the ensuing fight between Remain and Leave.Although not taking sides would avoid having to resign as Prime Minister in the scenario, EU leaders are unlikely to agree a new deal on Brexithe is not prepared to get behind it.The dissent is unlikely to be soothed by a new Ipsos Mori poll for Londonrsquos Evening Standard which found Mr Corbyn was the most unpopular opposition leader for  years.Just  per cent of voters approved of him, while % did not, a net -.It means Mr Corbyn is now even less popular than Labourrsquos Michael Foot, who hit - in , before he lost an election the following year.The same poll also found just % of Labour voters had done a good job on Brexit compared to % who said hersquod done a bad one.Ipsos Mori research director Keiran Pedley said Mr Corbynrsquos rating was ldquohistorically dire, but added: ldquoHe was able to signicantly improve his personal poll ratings during the  general election campaign so perhaps he will again.Shadow Foreign Secretary Emily Thornberry also sparked a row after comparing the LibDems to the Taliban for their new policy of cancelling Brexit without another referendum.She told the The House magazine: ldquoThe Lib Dems have gotten kind of Taliban, havenrsquot they  Theyrsquove said theyrsquore just going to revoke, therersquos not going to be another referendum. I donrsquot think itrsquos very democratic to seek to overturn a referendum without asking the people first.She also said she would be pushing for Labour to campaign for RemainldquoNot everyone agrees with me, so we need to thrash it out. The party has to decide collectively, she said.LibDem leader Jo Swinson said the Taliban remark was ldquoludicrous.Meanwhile Harrier Harman is at loggerheads with her local party after it said she should not try to replace John Bercow as Commons Speaker.The Camberwell  Peckham branch passed a motion saying the seat would lose a voiceits MP gave up her party colours for the role, and hinted Ms Harman could face a Labour opponentshe stood for re-election as Speaker.Ms Harman, a former deputy leader of the party, and the longest serving female MP, insisted she would be ldquogoing for it regardless.She tweeted: ldquoIrsquorsquoll always be there for the people of Camberwell  Peckham as I have throughout the last  years.... my commitment to them will be unshakableI become Speaker. The overwhelming majority of members of Camberwell  Peckham Labour Party understand the importance of a strong  fair Speaker  support me in this bid. I will not back down! #SpeakHer.Scottish Labour will today kick off the conference with a warning that household savings have fallen almost pound, since the Tories came to power in , a % drop.

title: carlaw-facing-questions-tory-dark-money-unit
story: Acting leader Jackson Carlaw has also been askedhe willor continue to receive money from the Scottish Unionist Association Trust , which has given the party more than pound, since .The Electoral Commission this week fined the SUAT a total of pound for three offences related to undeclared income of more than pound, and pound, of spending.The watchdog said the SUAT ldquoconsistently failed to provide proper notication of its activities as an unincorporated association and as a members association and as a result the public ldquodid not have the transparency it was entitled to have of SUATrsquos finances.The -year-old SUAT, which was at the heart of a row over so-called Tory lsquodark moneyrsquo, or untraceable funds, accepted the findings and paid the fines last month.It blamed ldquoadministrative errors, but stressed the Commission had found its donations to the Scottish Tories to have been permissible.The Scottish Tories said the fine was a matter for the SUAT, but stressed the donations it received had been ldquoproperly reported by the Conservative party.However, SNP MP Pete Wishart has now written to Mr Carlaw demanding ldquofull details of ties between the party and the SUAT.In particular, he asked what discussions took place between SUAT and the Scottish Tories before the  general election about how to spend an undeclared pound, bequest recently given to the trust.He also askedthe Tories would nowany donations ldquogiven the serious nature of the electoral offences committed by SUAT or would continue to take money from, and work with, the outfit.He said: ldquoElectoral law is in place to ensure that our democracy operates fairly and transparently and is not an lsquooptional extrarsquo which is there to be circumvented. Everything about SUAT and how it is structured and funded needs to be out in the open.ldquoWe also need to know the full relationship it has with the Scottish Conservatives. Without that there will remain the growing suspicion there is something to be hidden and covered up.A Scottish Tory spokesman said: ldquoIf Pete Wishart had bothered to read the judgment, hersquod know these donations were all properly reported by the party.

title: fund-save-waverley-gathers-steam-1m-boost
story: Culture Secretary Fiona Hyslop announced the leline for the Waverley Paddle Steamer, which has been in operation for over  years but needs pound.m to ride the waves once more.It has transported millions of passengers to a iety of locations throughout the UK but is currentlyout-of-service and requires new boilers.The Government fundingwill go towards replacing the twin boilers as well as other necessary maintenance and upkeep, such as replacing the main electrical switch board, new cabling and installing new generators.Ms Hyslop said: ldquoThe Waverley has delighted generations of locals and visitors throughout its -year history and I am pleased to be able to announce this signicant financial commitment to help the historic paddle steamer set sail again.ldquoIn  Scotlandrsquos coasts and waters will be celebrated with a programme of activity designed to inspire more people than ever before to explore and experience our unrivalled shores. I look forward to seeing the Waverley, such a key part of our maritime and cultural history, back in service and able to play a central part in that celebration.Waverley Excursions manager Paul Semple said:ldquoThe trustees are delightedthe Government hasrecognised the Waverleyrsquos importance to Scotlandrsquos heritage and tourism with this generous grant towards our Boiler Refit Appeal.ldquoTaken together with the donations received from thousands of iniduals across the UK it brings our appeal total to pound.m but more funding is required to reachour pound.m target to save the Waverley.ldquoThe continued support we are receiving is extremely heartening and we would like to sincerely thank everyone who has donated so far, we now hope that the corporate sector and grant-giving bodies will join the Government in supporting the Waverley toto service next summer.The Waverley Paddle Steamer undertook its maiden voyage in  and is registered as part of the National Historic Fleet as being a vessel of pre-eminent national signicance.

title: stand-together
story: Led by children wide-eyed and determined, their Fridays for Future movement wasfollowed en masse by adults, celebritiesand politicians, all making a stand againsta climate emergency that is fast becominga human catastrophe.Millions across the world took to their streets in one mass movement demanding that their governments, politicians, employers, business leaders, retailers, manufacturers, farmers, supermarkets, travel firms, energy providers and friends ndash do more. Tiny voices suddenly roared. Nations stood still.Images of young and the old standing together, home-made placards in hand, were beamed across borders as, first, Australia,then Indonesia, Europe, Africa, Antarctica, and, finally, North and South America joined in the biggest climate protestever seen.In the UK, hundreds of thousands of people took part. Children and students walked out of lessons and lectures and were joined by parents, campaigners and workers as part of global climate strikes that lookset to be the largest environmental protestsin history.:Billy Connolly joins Climate Strike in GlasgowThousands in Scotland, including children, joined millions of others across the world as part of a global climate strike.Marches were held in cities including Edinburgh, Glasgow, Dundee, Inverness, Perth and Aberdeen, and towns as far apart as Ullapool and Kirkcudbright, as well as throughout the UK.Stars including comedian Sir Billy Connelly joined them in support, businesses such as ScottishPower allowed staff free rein to take part too.More than , are thought to have marched in Edinburgh and , in Glasgow as crowds flocked on to the streets.The action was inspired by Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg, who began a seriesof school strikes last year in a call to tackle climate change.Dylan Hamilton, a member of Scottish Youth Climate Strike who helped organised the globalstrike told reporters: ldquoWe are making history by standing up for our future. The people have protested, we marched and then we rallied. We have made our position clear the government needs to act for the future of humanity. Politicians have spent decades sitting around talking, butyour house is burning down you wouldnrsquot stop to talk about money, you would act.ldquoAll those protesting today have shown that action has an impact.ldquoThere has never been a more important issue facing humanity than the climate crisis. With the week of action to come we will show that we wonrsquot go away, todayrsquos protest will show the world that the people want action that responds to what climate science demands.Erin Curtis, , from Glasgow said: ldquoItrsquos absolutely amazing to see so many people striking with us today. The fact that our streets have been filled with everyone demanding action sends a clear message to those in power that the public want to see change.ldquoThe momentum from people is there, we want a better future, and all of us uniting for this protest will drive home to the Government that we wonrsquot stand for platitudes any longer.Speaking at the rally in Glasgow, Scottish Greens co-leader Patrick Harvie said: ldquoThis younger generation is giving the leadership that my generation has failed to show.ldquoThese people know that their future is in peril and there is hopethis generation can take the political power that itrsquos capable of on a day like this.... itrsquos been amazing and it really gives me inspiration and hope for the future.ldquoYou look around the world at the problems that wersquore facing at the moment, yoursquod be forgiven for pulling the duvet over you, curling into a ball and trying to ignore the problems the world is facing.ldquoButa generation likes this discovers its political power by acting together, recognising that we need system changewersquore going to prevent climate change, then there is real hope.:Pupils taking part in climate strikes should not be punished, says unionLiberal Democrat leader Jo Swinson was also at the Glasgow climate march and called for radical proposals to tackle climate change.She said: ldquoIt was inspiring to see so many determined young people at the Glasgow Youth Climate March today. We all urgently need to raise awareness of the climate crisis and demand strong action to stop irreversible damage.ldquoProtecting the planet for future generations is a cause close to my heart, when I think of my own two boys. They, and all children, cannot be made to pay because Governments like our current one did not take action in time.Erin Hicks, nine, who goes to school in Edinburgh, was taking part in the march with his family.He said people should respect the climate and help protect polar bears, adding:ldquoI just think that we should try to save the planet. I have got lots of friends here ndash I went on the march with one of my friends and lots of us are off school.Our teachers encourage us to think about the world and help the climate.Erin said he wanted politicians to stop giving money to the oil industry and to cut down on plastics.Elsewhere, Cameron Du Puy, , also urged politicians to find a way to ditch single-use plastics.He said: ldquoWe are here to stop climate change, so we can have a future ndash so children can have a future and the planet will be safe.Cameronrsquos mum Raine said it was ldquoutterly fabulous to see so many children getting involved, adding: ldquoThey learn about it in school now, which is great.ldquoItrsquos quite inspiring as well, even just seeing what people have written on their banners and the dferent ideas that come from that.David Goldberg, , a student at Edinburgh University, praised the ldquocommunity spirit fostered by the march. He said: ldquoItrsquos really good. We have got a generation of people that really care about the planet. Thatrsquos really nice. Itrsquos something more than a protest. Itrsquos a group of people who are likeminded. Itrsquos a massive community, in a way.Tiggy Wilkes, , also a student, said the strike showed ldquostrength in numbers.She said: ldquoThis is one of the best ways to show our support. Itrsquos great to see everyone here.Jamie Livingstone, Head of Oxfam Scotland, said: ldquoFrom the surge in support for Greta Thunberg to the global school strike movement, it is inspiring to see the next generation demand urgent and sustained action on the climate crisis.ldquoHaving helped to cause this crisis, rich countries like Scotland have a moral obligation to the worldrsquos poorest countries where the current generation is already living with the le-and-death consequences of decades of inaction.Young people around the globe ndash including in Scotland ndash know this is wrong, and that things need to change.ldquoWersquore joining these huge marches on Scotlandrsquos streets because the climate emergency requires an emergency response, and we want to echo the school strikersrsquo call to world leaders to match rhetoric with immediate and lasting policy changes.ldquoNext week, MSPs will vote to write the Climate Change Bill into law and they must prove they are listening to the young people up and down the country demanding tougher and faster action. Reducing our emissions quickly in the next  years is essentialwe are to help prevent this climate emergency from becoming a global climate catastrophe.Ahead of the strike action, the Scottish Government said it is ldquoleading by example through its bold actions to address the climate emergency.A spokesman said: ldquoThe global climate emergency and a Green New Deal for Scotland are at the centre of our Programme for Government.ldquoWe are leading by example through bold actions. We are redoubling our efforts and we will end Scotlandrsquos contribution to global climate change by .In London, where estimates put crowds at ,, Green Party politician Caroline Lucas said: ldquoIt feels like there is a real uprising. It feels like there is a real sense from young people in particular that they simply wonrsquot wait any longer.ldquoIt is their future that is at stake and our generation, my generation is responsible for not having done nearly enough to address that.ldquoThey have enormous moral authority when they tell us that.Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn told the youth movement that ldquoyou and a whole generation have brought the issue centre stage and I am absolutely delighted about that.:Demand for post-Brexitenvironmentprotection laws as Scots show support in pollHe criticised US President Donald Trump for his failure to act on climate change and had a message for Brazilrsquos President Jair Bolsonaro that he wanted to work with him to preserve and protect the Amazon rainforest.One of the protesters, Jessica Ahmed, , from Barnet, north London, said: ldquoSchool is important but so is my future, and called on the Government to acknowledge the severity of the climate crisis.ldquoIf politicians were taking the appropriate action we need and had been taking this action a long time ago when it was recognised the world was changing in a negative way, then I would not have to be skipping school.In Belfast, organisers put the turnout at between , and ,, with young people taking over the Corn Market area of the city centre and staging a ldquomass die-in, before marching towards City Hall.Some of Fridayrsquos first protests were held in Australia, where an estimated , people gathered at more than  rallies calling for action to guard against climate change.Some of the first rallies were held in Australiarsquos largest city, Sydney, and the national capital, Canberra. Australian demonstrators called for their nation - the worldrsquos largest exporter of coal and liquid natural gas - to take more drastic action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.Organisers estimated more than , protesters took to Australian streets in what would be the largest demonstrations in the country since the Iraq War began in .In Thailand hundreds of people marched in the streets of the capital Bangkok to demand the government takes measures to deal with the climate change crisis.An organiser said about  people, mostly children with their parents, took part. Many were Westerners.Organiser, -year-old Nanticha Ocharoenchai, said the demonstrators stopped at the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment to submit an open letter demanding the government declare a climate emergency, ban coal energy by  and completely replace fossil fuel energy with renewable energy by .The protesters staged a ldquodie-in outside the ministry to dramatise their concerns, lying down on the pavement with many clutching home-made signs with slogans such as ldquoClean air is our right.Dozens of students and environmental activist sin India gathered in the capital demanding immediate action. They assembled outside the Ministry of Housing and Urban Affairs in New Delhi.They chanted slogans like ldquoWe want climate action and ldquoI want to breathe clean, and carried banners with messages like ldquoThere is no earth B and ldquoEco, not ego!About  people with banners and posters chanted ldquostop the pollution as they marched along the harbour front in Hong Kong under a blazing sun. Organiser Dhanada Mishra, a visiting scholar atIn Berlin, organisers said , people gathered in front of the capitalrsquos landmark Brandenburg Gate, not far from Chancellor Angela Merkelrsquos office where the cabinet was thrashing out the final details of a plan to curb Germanyrsquos greenhouse gas emissions.Police said several dozen activists also blocked a road in the heart of Frankfurt, Germanyrsquos financial capital.Dozens of activists marched in Manila in the Philippines to honour the memory of activists in the Philippines who were killed for defending the environment.They marched to the offices of the Environment and Natural Resources Department, then staged a ldquodie-in protest while holding a banner saying ldquoStop the killings. Defend the environment defenders now!The group Global Witness says the Philippines had the highest number of killings of environmental defenders of any country in , with at least  murdered.A separate rally organised by student groups gathered in the afternoon at the state university. Hundreds participated bunched together to hold placards forming an image of the earth, with a big sign that said ldquoThere is no Planet B.Many middle schools gave students the day off in Poland to enable them to take part in the global climate protest. Thousands joined colourful marches with banners reading ldquoThere is NO Planet B in the capital Warsaw and many other cities.Critics say the government is dragging its feet on its programme of subsidies for families who do away with coal-burning heaters that are largely responsible for smog, especially in southern regions.A coal-producing nation with tens of thousands of jobs in mining, Poland gets % of its energy from fossil fuels. The governmentrsquos plan for phasing coal out is slow paced, reaching to .Afghanistan saw about  young people, with several young women in the front carrying a banner emblazoned with ldquoFridays for future, marched through central Kabul, following an armoured personnel carrier deployed for their protection as well as half a dozen army personnel behind them and along the route.Fardeen Barakzai, one of the organisers and head of the local climate group called Oxygen, said: ldquoWe want to do our part. We as the youth of our country know the problem of climate change. We know war can kill a group of people... the problem in Afghanistan is our leaders are fighting for power but the real power is in nature.:Brexit threatens to wipe out Scotlands rarest animals and put at risk iconic landscapesThousands of students gathered in the Old Town Square in Prague, waving banners that read ldquoMore love, less coal, ldquoScience, not silence and ldquoWhy should we go to universities when they donrsquot listen to the educated  before marching through the city.Organisers say rallies are taking place in about  places across the country.In neighbouring Slovakia, President Zuzana Caputova has thrown her weight behind thousands of students rallying in four major cities, including the capital of Bratislava.A sign reading ldquoLawmaker: know your climate stood out in a sea of umbrellas during the event in Copenhagen. Smaller demonstrations were held in other Danish cities.In Finlandrsquos capital Helsinki, a man dressed as Santa Claus stood outside parliament holding a sign that said: ldquoMy house is on fire, my reindeer canrsquot swim. A rally in Swedish capital Stockholm snaked through the city centre behind a banner reading ldquoSchool strike for climate.Teenagers and children as young as  in Paris traded classrooms for the streets to call on their government to do more to combat climate change.Chanting ldquoanti-capitalism and ldquojoin us, donrsquot watch us, they marched from the Place de la Nation to Parc de Bercy. The demonstration took on a festival-like feel as bands played and youngsters danced in the eastern Paris park.Hundreds joined demonstrations in several cities in Bosnia, Croatia, Montenegro and Serbia, demanding action to protect the environment and address pollution.In the southern Bosnian city of Mostar, about  high school students held a protest march. Some held banners that read: ldquoSave the World and ldquoOur home is burning!Several hundred young people gathered in Split, on Croatiarsquos Adriatic Sea coast, carrying a huge banner that urged, ldquoSplit, wake up! Activists warned Split could face flooding due to global warming. Dozens of people also marched through Serbiarsquos capital Belgrade and in Montenegrorsquos capital Podgorica.Banners in Kenyarsquos capital Nairobi ranged from angry to playful, with one reading: ldquoThis planet is getting hotter than my imaginary boyfriend. Other protests are taking place in Johannesburg and the South African capital Pretoria. Hundreds of people gathered in Johannesburg chanted and waved signs saying ldquoClimate justice now and ldquoTherersquos only one Earth.Experts say Africa is the most vulnerable continent to climate change and the least equipped to deal with it. Governments have pleaded for more support from the international community.Residents of Africarsquos most populous city, Lagos in Nigeria, joined the demonstrations.Environmentalist Desmond Majekodunmi said for the first time all of humanity faces a threat to their very existence, ldquoso the only way we can overcome that problem is by coming together, forgetting our dferences.The UN climate summit takes place in New York next week, Greta Thunberg among those taking part, to emphasise her perhaps prophetic words that resonated around the world again yesterday of how ldquono-one is too small to make a dference.

title: issue-day-friends-turns-25
story: Friends is really celebrating its silver anniversary The first episode aired on September , , introducing Monica, Rachel, Phoebe, Chandler, Ross and Joey, six late  early -somethings who were facing le and love in the Big Apple.How many episodes were there  series, so  episodes, all airing on NBC in the US and Channel  in the UK, with the finale airing in May . Friends began streaming on Netflix in the UK in late , with repeats airing on Comedy Central as well.Why has it taken a bit of flak lately Millennials catching up with the show havenrsquot been able to get on board with certain storylines, saying it wouldnrsquot work now due to its LGBT plot points ndash when Chandler was uneasy about his cross-dressing father or paranoid about being perceived as homosexual. Some viewers point out sexism is re too, for example, when Rachel hires a male assistant based only on his looks.Where are the stars now The show propelled the main actors to global fame. David Schwimmer got rave reviews for his role asOJ Simpsonrsquos lawyer in The People v OJ Simpson in  and recently guest-starred in the revival of Will  Grace. Matthew Perry appeared as Ted Kennedy in an American mini-series The Kennedys After Camelot, in , but his re-boot of The Odd Couple was cancelled after  episodes the same year. He was the last of the Friends stars to turn , hitting the big number in August.What about the others Courteney Cox, who is dating Snow Patrol guitarist Johnny McDaid, is the creative force behind Facebook pregnancy docu-series  Months With Courteney Cox. Lisa Kudrow hasnrsquot stopped working as an actor and is also the executive producer of the US version of Who Do You Think You Are What about Matt Le Blanc The actor who played Joey Tribbiani is perhaps the most successful of all, earning a Golden Globe for his role as a fictionalised version of himself in Episodes. He also co-hosted Top Gear from  to  and currently stars in US sitcom Man with a Plan.What about Jenner Aniston Brad Pittrsquos ex-wersquos latest movie role is in a Netflix film, Murder Mystery, with Adam Sandler,while she also stars in the Apple TV drama The Morning Show, with Reese Witherspoon, her firstmain TV rolesince Friends ended. When asked about a Friends reunion, she told US TV host Ellen in June: ldquoAnything could happen.But could it If yoursquore a Friends fan I hate to burst your bubble, but it seems unlikely. Show creator Marta Kauffman said last week, ldquoWewill not be doing a reunion show, we will not be doing a reboot.So it looks like the Friends willstill only be there for you on streaming.

title: jeremy-corbyn-wont-offer-indyref2-win-snp-support-hung-parliament
story: In a round of ITV regional news interviews, he saidthere was a hung parliament and they were unable to achieve an overall majority, Labour would seek to govern as a minority government - ruling out any deal with the SNP."We would go into government with whatever election result was. I am not doing deals. I am not doing coalitions," he said.ComRes polling suggeststhe Conservatives fall short of a majority Labour could form an alliance with the Lib Dems and SNP to form a government.:Willie Rennie: Indyref should be blocked eventhe SNP Greens win Holyrood electionHowever, he refused to rule out a further public vote later in the parliamentthere was a demand for one in Scotland."It is not our priority. It is not what I want, it is not what I support," he said."Butafter some years in government there is a demand, then in terms of the devolution settlement we will look at it at that time."Speaking on STV, he added: "Obviously in the longer run,a request is made ... I am not going to be the one who stands in the way of that."Mr Corbyn said that he would press for a general election once it was clear that Boris Johnson could not force through a no-deal Brexit against the wishes of parliament.:Poll finds UK-wide support for second independence and Northern Irish border referendum that could break up union"When the prime minister abides by the law which parliament has passed which requires himhe cannot get a deal to apply for an extension, I think that is the time," he said.His comments came after shadow chancellor John McDonnell sparked a row over the summer when he suggested a Labour government would not stand in the way of a referendumthere was support for one in the Scottish Parliament.However, the leader of Scottish Labour, Richard Leonard, said at the time that the referendum in  had been a "once-in-a-generation vote" and that the Scottish people did not want to go through a second independence poll.

title: mnd-campaigner-lucy-lintott-expecting-baby-boy
story: Just a few months after announcing her engagement, the Evening Times Scotswoman of the Yearrevealed on social media that she is expecting a baby boy.Doctors believe she is the first person ever with Motor Neurone Disease to become pregnant post-diagnosis."They told us there are no known cases anywhere of someone with MND becoming pregnant," said Lucy."But my womb is unaffected by MND so in theory I should have a normal pregnancy and be able to have a natural birth."She added: "I see a consultant and get scanned once a month, and the doctors have said they will just have to play things by ear - just like any other mum-to-be. If there are complications then we will deal with them - just like anyone .":Lucy invites world to see le with MND: "I am slowly going paralysed"Lucys Twitter post read: ldquoWersquore delighted to announce that early next year wersquoll be bringing our baby boy into the world!It was accompanied by a picture of Lucy, proudly showing off her bump, with fianceacute Tommy Smith who proposed to her in May.ldquoWersquore so happy, she said. ldquoItrsquos been a tiring few months, Ive had loads of morning sickness and wersquore planning our wedding too - but Irsquom fine. I just get very tired so I have to be careful. Im taking a break from fundraising just now to concentrate on staying healthy."Lucy added with a laugh: "Both our families are so excited. My mum cannot wait to be a granny! She is over the moon."The baby is due at the end of February, and Lucy and Tommy have set a wedding date for the end of May."Im still hoping I can get to Scotswoman of the Year too," she laughed.Lucy, from Garmouth in Moray, was diagnosed with Motor Neurone Disease, an incurable condition which usually affects people over , when she was just .MND gradually makes gripping, walking, talking and swallowing extremely dficult and eventually impossible.Since the devastating diagnosis six years ago, Lucy has opened up her le to help other sufferers, and has raised pound, to help find a cure.:Young MND sufferer honoured by Prime MinisterShe was crowned Evening Times Scotswoman of the Year in  for her inspirational awareness-raising campaign.Lucyrsquos blog,has inspired people all over the world. She wrote a bucket list of things she wanted to do, including many helping other people going through dficult times, and began raising money to help the search for a cure.With the help of her mum and dad, Lydia and Robert, and brother and sister Ross and Laura, Lucy made a documentary for the BBC, called MND and -year-old Me, which was viewed by more than half a million people.

title: scottish-flight-delayed-allow-baby-hedgehog-cross-runway
story: The Loganair flight was taxiing to the runway in Stornoway, Lewis, when the prickly creature made an appearance.The captain brought the Saab  aircraft to a halt at around .pm on Thursday and waited two minutes for the creature to cross.The  passengers on board were alerted about the reason for the delay in their journey to Inverness in the Highlands.:Loganair adds new routesNeil Hughes, Loganairrsquos director of flight operations, said: ldquoThe captain safely avoided a prickly situation for the little hedgehog, following procedure until the animal was off the tarmac.@FlyLoganair While departing Stornoway Airport yesterday evening the plane was heading to the runway when it came to a sudden stop.After a short time the captain announced he has stopped to let a baby hedgehog cross over in front of him! #loganair #logancareldquoOur network extends into some of Scotlandrsquos most remote communities so there are quite a few opportunities to see animals in the wild ndash and wersquore always conscious to disturb them as little as possible.:A better way to travel to London with LoganairPilots operating from Stornoway regularly scan the runway for wildle, given the rural location of the airport in the Outer Hebrides.One passenger, Roddy Macleod said: I was on the LM from Stornoway to Inverness at  pm when the aircraft was taxing towards the runway when all of a sudden the brakes went on like an emergency stop!"After a minute the captain came over the radio telling us that he was waiting on a baby hedgehog to pass."Lynn Valentine said her husband has to work in Stornoway sometimes and this was his excuse for being late home.She said on social media: "Itrsquos true! Flight delayed by baby hedgehog on Stornoway Airport runway."

title: herald-diary-brought-book
story: WRITING can be taxing work, as reader Harvey Sandison discovered. On retiring, he planned to complete a novel. Every morning Harvey trudged to the attic with his laptop. After six months of black moods and white paper, untarnished by words, he called off the project. Back in the real world, Harveyrsquos we descended with a y list of tasks: pictures to hang, gadgets to mend etc. ldquoI thought I achieved nothing in that attic, Harvey sighs. ldquoLooking back, I avoided a whole load of somethings up there, which was achievement enough.Room to roamROD Stewart has revealed the secret of his successful marriage to Penny Lancaster. A big house with numerous rooms to avoid each other. Although aware Rod lives in a mansion, the Diary is disappointed to learn most rooms are used for matrimonial hide-and-seek. We hoped they stored Rodrsquos vast and tasteful collection of clothes. One room packed with leopard-print trousers, for instance. Plus a gold-lame sock mezzanine. Perhaps even an entire wing of the house festooned with string vests studded with diamonds and rubies. Hey ho. There goes another rock rumour.Dog day afternoonDOUG Angus was so fond of his pipe he refused all entreaties to give it up, even when they came from his we and daughters. He was deprived of baccy for several weeks, however, while suffering from flu. Fully recovered and relaxing in the lounge with his pet dog, our man decided toto his errant ways. The mutt, quietly observing his master reaching for his pipe, stood up, pawed open the door and vacated the room.Such doggy dismissiveness was too much for Doug. You seldom see those little fellows roaming the streets at night.Hynde sightJIM Kerrrsquos ex, Chrissie Hynde, admits shersquos looking for love at the age of . title: doors open days events to be held
story: This Saturday and Sunday will see Orkney#s biggest ever Doors Open Days event.Doors Open Days is Scotland#s largest free cultural festival, celebrating the built environment and giving free access to around one thousand venues across Scotland throughout the weekends of September, every year.It provides free access to sites of historic, cultural or community interest, increasing public appreciation and enjoyment of Scotland#s built heritage.The event is co-ordinated by the Scottish Civic Trust, and supported by Historic Environment Scotland.Last year, Orkney had two places participating in Orkney for Doors Open Days — the Fossil centre, and the Storytelling Centre. This year Orkney boasts seven venues — some of which are participating for the first time,As far as local people are concerned, Doors Open Days is about getting into buildings for free and seeing things that you don#t often see. If buildings are usually charging an entrance fee they can take part by offering to open for free,The event benefits the organisations or venues by attracting more visitors. It helps them by becoming more involved in the community, as a volunteer or a visitor, and enhancing appreciation of local architecture and local heritage.The seven venues taking part in Orkney all have free entry. For their opening times see the Orkney Doors Open Day or visit the main Doors Open Day website. title: hoolan wind projects win government contracts
story: Orkney is to become part of a #green energy powerhouse#, said the UK Government, this morning, Friday, as they awarded contracts to two controversial wind farms in the county.Projects at Costa Head in Evie and Hesta Head in South Ronaldsay, developed by Hoolan Energy, have been named as part of a package of  wind farms to win #contracts for dference# — which allow the companies to sell energy at lower prices.The scheme is the government’s main mechanism for supporting new renewable electricity generation project. Successful generators still sell the electricity they produce on the wholesale market but receive a #top-up# payment over the course of the -year contract.Changes made to rules which had forbidden all onshore wind projects from competing in the electricity market in  meant projects in the Western Isles, Shetland and Orkney were able to compete.Prime Minister Boris Johnson said: “The UK is leading the way in the fight against climate change, and it’s great news that millions more homes will be powered by clean energy at record low prices.“Seizing the opportunities of clean energy not only helps to protect our planet, but will also back businesses and boost jobs across the UK.”Though they may have won favour with the government, Hoolan#s two Orkney projects have previously been met with protest from the public and rejection by councillors. More than  protestors took to School Place, last September, when the projects appeared before the OIC planning committee. Though there were no statutory objections to either project, there were  letters of objection and  of support for the Costa project. The Hesta Project, meanwhile, received a total of  objections and nine letters of support.Though councillors elected to reject the wind farms, this decision was later overturned by the Scottish Government. This sparked criticism from former planning chairman, Councillor Owen Tierney, who accused the government of #lacking faith# in the local planning system.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: hygrogen plane tests set for orkney
story: A project which could see the entire aviation industry in Orkney decarbonised has been given huge financial backing.The HyFlyer project aims to decarbonise medium range small passenger aircraft by demonstrating hydrogen fuel cell powertrain technology.It is a project which presents signicant opportunities in Orkney since all flights from Kirkwall could potentially be serviced by this new technology.The project has been awarded £. million of UK Government funding and will culminate in a  nautical mile demonstration flight out of Orkney by .Orkney Islands Council leader James Stockan said: “In Orkney we are seeking to be clean, green islands.#Transport is our biggest decarbonisation challenge, with our remote and rural setting placing our islanders in the position of producing a signicant carbon footprint.“Initiatives like this are presenting us with opportunities to reduce this carbon footprint and support Orkney Islands Council’s climate emergency declaration. I look forward to the project progressing.”Led by ZeroAvia, developers of hydrogen fuel cell powertrain solutions, HyFlyer will demonstrate a phased approach from battery power to hydrogen power, integrating the new technology aboard a Piper M-class six-seater aircraft which will perform test flights out of Cranfield and Orkney.Project partners Intelligent Energy will optimise its high power fuel cell technology for application in aviation while EMEC Hydrogen, producers of green hydrogen from renewable energy, will supply the hydrogen required for flight tests and develop a mobile refuelling  compatible with the plane.The HyFlyer project will see conventional piston engines in propeller aircraft replaced by electric motors, hydrogen fuel cells and gas storage.If all goes well, ZeroAvia, based in Calornia, are aiming to supply the technology to commercial manufacturers by .Following this demonstration, the next goal then is to power an aircraft, carrying up to  passengers, to travel  miles.According to the Air Transport Action Group, aviation is responsible for  per cent of CO emissions from all transport sources and is one of the fastest growing sources of global emissions.Val Mtakhov, founder and CEO of ZeroAvia, said: “The substantial backing provided by the UK Government underlines the potential that hydrogen holds as a fuel source for commercial aviation and provides signicant validation of ZeroAvia’s approach to zero emission flight.“Our project goal of  NM is equivalent to the distance from London to Edinburgh and will prove that zero emission aviation, powered by hydrogen, can play a key role within the UK and other countries’ transport strategies — enabling net zero targets to be met and improving productivity and regional prosperity.”Richard Ainsworth, Hydrogen Project Specialist at EMEC Hydrogen, said: “HyFlyer is another key step in Orkney’s aim to decarbonise leline transport services for islanded communities.#Hydrogen has the potential to help meet our emission commitments where electrons and batteries can’t.#This project sees us one step closer to meeting our fuel and energy needs from abundant local renewable energy resources using green hydrogen.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: msp backs rnli for its work home and abroad
story: Highlands and Islands MSP Jamie Halcro Johnston has given strong backing to the RNLI following criticism in a national newspaper of the charity’s work overseas.The Conservative MSP submitted a motion to the Scottish Parliament this week in which he praised the RNLI’s efforts across the UK, while also highlighting the importance of building lesaving capacity around the world.Mr Halcro Johnston, from Orkney, said: “As someone from one of Scotland’s islands, where the sea is so much a part of everyone’s lives, we know how vital the work of the RNLI is, as well as the bravery of those who risks their lives to venture out in the worst sea conditions to save the lives of others.“However, the RNLI’s work isn’t just rescuing those in trouble far out to sea, but much of their work is closer to shore where swimmers and others who enjoy our coasts can often find themselves in dficulty.“The RNLI is a leader in making le safer for all those who enjoy our coasts. And so surely it is both appropriate and welcome that it seeks to make its expertise and experience available to those trying to save lives in other countries, and supports those efforts where they can “Much of the work the RNLI is doing overseas appears to be targeted at young people and children – helping making the water safer for them # and that is something I would fully support.“As someone who has, from a very early age, helped raise funds for the RNLI, I am proud of its work home and abroad, and I thank every crew member, volunteer, fundraiser and supporter for all their efforts.#copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
